name: SWGA
tagline: Workflow to select primers for selective whole-genome amplification (SWGA)
body:
# Selective whole genome amplification
Selective whole-genome amplification (SWGA) is a way to specifically amplify a target genome over background sample DNA. 
For instance, we can design a set of primers that amplify a parasite's genome in a sample that is overwhelmingly composed of host DNA. For more information, see [Leichty & Brisson, _Genetics_, 2014](http://www.genetics.org/content/198/2/473.long).

This software is built to find sets of compatible PCR primers that can be used for SWGA. It can be run on a range of hardware, from personal laptops to computing clusters and servers.

## Features:
- Counts all the possible primers in a size range in both genomes
- Filters primers based on:
  - foreground and background genome binding rates
  - melting temperatures (with a built-in melt temp calculator that accounts for mono- and divalent cation solutions!)
  - Possible homodimerization
- Finds primer sets containing primers that are compatible with each other using graph theory (largest clique formation). The process ensures:
  - No primer in a set is a heterodimer
  - Even binding site spacing in foreground genome
  - Low total binding to background genome
- Score each set based on certain binding metrics and allows exploration of high-scoring sets via output to common formats.

## Using SWGA

Follow the installation instructions [here](https://github.com/eclarke/swga/wiki/Installation), then visit [Quick Start](https://github.com/eclarke/swga/wiki) to get started!

### Quick start:

- [Install guide](https://github.com/eclarke/swga/wiki/Installation)
- [Getting started](https://github.com/eclarke/swga/wiki/)

### Support

Check out the wiki, mailing list (swga-dev@googlegroups.com), or contact me at @eclarke.
